docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students examine some old wives' tales and folk remedies related to health, learn about the science behind why people might believe them to be true, and investigate the real scientific causes or reasons for their effects.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students examine some old wives' tales and folk remedies related to health, learn about the science behind why people might believe them to be true, and investigate the real scientific causes or reasons for their effects.

byline.original: By ALISON ZIMBALIST and YASMIN CHIN EISENHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: The 15-year-old girl who left her newborn son in a trash can has been charged with attempted murder. The mother, a freshman at Bergenfield High School, managed to hide her pregnancy, and gave birth in the bathroom of her home on Friday night. She placed the baby in a gym bag and dumped it in a trash can outside a deli near her house, Sgt. Brian Monaghan of the Bergenfield police said. Bergen County's assistant prosecutor, James Santulli, said that the girl would be prosecuted as a juvenile. The baby was in critical condition at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center yesterday.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bergenfield: Girl Charged With Attempted Murder

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the lessons of the tsunami a year ago is that however stingy we Americans have been in giving foreign aid, we want to do better.

headline.main: Waging a War We Could Be Proud Of

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no secret that some women who take birth control pills lose interest in sex. They have been reporting this side effect to their doctors since oral contraceptives came into wide use 40 years ago. ''Little by little, my boyfriend and I started noticing that I was just never in the mood. Never,'' said Cody, a 27-year-old San Francisco woman, who asked that her last name not be used for reasons of privacy.

headline.main: When the Pill Arouses That Urge for Abstinence

docs.abstract: Boston urologist Dr Irwin Goldstein conducts study on reported link between decreased sexual desire in women and use of birth control pills; finds that sexual function does not immediately return for most women after discontinuing pills and suggests that elevated levels of sex hormone binding globulin, protein that renders free testosterone in blood inactive, is responsible; other theories about sexual desire and impact of birth control pills discussed; research is published in Journal of Sexual Medicine; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A controversial new study suggests that the birth control pill not only suppresses desire, but can also do so for months after a woman stops taking it.

docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.

headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis
headline.sub: One Day in the Trenches ;As Cases Surge in New York, So Do Fears Of an Overburdened Medical System ;

docs.snippet: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Begin on the sixth floor, third room from the end, swathed in fluorescence: a 60-year-old woman was having two toes sawed off. One floor up, corner room: a middle-aged man sprawled, recuperating from a kidney transplant. Next door: nerve damage. Eighth floor, first room to the left: stroke. Two doors down: more toes being removed. Next room: a flawed heart. As always, the beds at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx were filled with a universe of afflictions. In truth, these assorted burdens were all the work of a single illness: diabetes. Room after room, floor after floor, diabetes. On any given day, hospital officials say, nearly half the patients are there for some trouble precipitated by the disease.

headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1996, Salim Hamdan, a 26-year-old Yemeni with a thick mustache and kinky black hair, was working part time as a taxi driver, dividing his modest income between the mattress he rented in a crowded boardinghouse in the dirty, bustling city of Sana and his daily supply of khat leaves, the stimulant that most Yemeni men chew by the fistful. Then one day the low-hanging horizon of his life lifted: he was recruited for jihad. He joined about 35 other Muslims, mostly Yemenis, who were preparing to leave for Tajikistan to fight alongside that country's small Islamic insurgency against its Russian-backed government.

headline.main: The Bush Administration vs. Salim Hamdan

docs.abstract: Jonathan Mahler article on Salim Hamdan, Yemeni being detained at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, awaiting trial for conspiracy by special military tribunal established by Pres Bush in aftermath of 9/11; his lawyers do not deny that Hamdan worked directly for Osama bin Laden, but portray him as uneducated and far-from-devout driver and mechanic who was grateful for paycheck but generally ignorant of terrorist enterprise for which he worked; contend that tribunals are illegal and should not go forward; government has not accused Hamdan of being member of Al Qaeda per se, but charges that he did pick up and deliver weapons for use by Qaeda associates, trained at Qaeda camp and served as bodyguard and driver for bin Laden; Supreme Court will hear case in spring; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The government's efforts to maintain its special military tribunals  and perhaps its approach to the war on terror  may come down to one suspected terrorist.
